title: Education technology company to close Boston headquarters, embrace fully remote workplace
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Cengage Group will close its Boston, Detroit, and Cincinnati offices and adopt a fully remote work model.
The education technology firm has nearly 4,000 employees and serves around 90 million students in 125 countries.
Cengage's only remaining U.S. location is in Independence, Ky., as the company evaluates future office space needs.

title: What Patriots players did during their off day that impressed Mike Vrabel
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: 41 Patriots players utilized their off day for workouts at Gillette Stadium, impressing head coach Mike Vrabel.
Tuesday is typically the only off day for players during the NFL season, emphasizing commitment by Patriots players.
Stefon Diggs emphasized the importance of the team not getting complacent despite their current 7-2 season record.

title: Officials identify two killed in apparent murder-suicide in Beverly
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Becky Lynn Center, 58, and John Patrick Nesbitt, 56, found dead in Beverly home with gunshot wounds.
Incident on Colonial Drive is considered an apparent murder-suicide, say authorities.
Beverly police, Massachusetts State Police, and the Chief Medical Examiner's Office are investigating.

title: South Boston man linked to Bulger sentenced to 15 years for involvement in 1984, 1993 cold case killings
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Michael Lewis, 65, was sentenced to 15 years for manslaughter in the 1984 and 1993 deaths of Brian Watson and William Villani.
Initially charged with first-degree murder, Lewis pleaded guilty to reduced manslaughter charges in a negotiated agreement with the DA's office.
Lewis was linked to notorious gangster James 'Whitey' Bulger and admitted to the killings in a covert 2020 recording.

title: Olney: Red Sox ‘well-positioned’ to try and trade for Tigers ace Tarik Skubal
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox are reportedly 'well-positioned' to trade for Tigers' ace Tarik Skubal this offseason, according to ESPN's Buster Olney.
Tarik Skubal, 28, won the 2024 AL Cy Young Award and led the league in ERA (2.21) and WHIP (0.891) in 2025.
Red Sox have the assets and financial means to pursue Skubal, considering possible trade assets like Jarren Duran and Marcelo Mayer.

title: Judge temporarily halts patron saint statues in Quincy, but PETA wants to help
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: A judge temporarily blocked the installation of two bronze patron saint statues outside Quincy's new public safety building.
PETA offered financial assistance for the project if Quincy adds a statue of St. Francis of Assisi, patron saint of animals.
The ACLU filed a lawsuit against the statues, citing religious concerns; an appeal was filed by the city with Becket Fund.

title: Bill Belichick commends Drake Maye for an ‘outstanding’ start with Patriots
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick praises Patriots QB Drake Maye, noting his impressive start and contribution to their 7-2 record.
Drake Maye is a strong MVP candidate, completing 74.1% of passes for 2,285 yards and 17 touchdowns.
Belichick warns of sophomore slump risks, comparing Maye's rise to the Washington Commanders' struggles with Jayden Daniels.

title: Here’s how many people visited Salem this past Halloween
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Salem welcomed 96,000 visitors on Halloween Day 2025, a 7.2% increase from the previous year.
The ongoing government shutdown led to the closure of several government-run buildings in Salem.
Over October 2025, Salem received 1.1 million unique visitors, maintaining the record from the prior year.

title: ‘Whitey’ Bulger mugshot comes down at Savin Hill restaurant after backlash
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Savin Bar and Kitchen removed Whitey Bulger and Stephen Flemmi mugshots after backlash from the local community.
The mugshots were initially part of renovations following a feature on Gordon Ramsay's "Secret Service" show.
Owner Ken Osherow replaced them with historical photos amidst criticism for insensitivity towards Bulger's impact on Boston.

title: Have you seen snowliage — that wild mix of fall leaves and winter snow?
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: 'Snowliage' refers to the mix of fall foliage and early snow, a rare occurrence in New England.
Phil Bobrow captured snowliage images in Vermont, showcasing the collision of colorful leaves and fresh snow.
Residents are encouraged to share their snowliage experiences with Boston.com for potential feature stories.
